Award.AwardTitle: IGERT: The Dynamics of Brain-Body-Environment Systems in Behavior and Cognition

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) award supports a training program on the dynamics of brain-body-environment interaction in behavior and cognition at Indiana University. The purpose of the training program is to create a new kind of scientist with expertise in both the experimental and theoretical tools necessary to analyze intelligence as an emergent property of a complex dynamic system. The training program includes new courses, a professional development seminar, a colloquium series that provides opportunities for extended interactions between students and top researchers, research internships, and opportunities for international collaboration. The program also includes a detailed assessment plan and a summer program for undergraduates from underrepresented groups run in partnership with Indiana University Northwest, approximately 80% of whose students come from minority, first-generation college, female or low socioeconomic categories. Broader impacts of this program include recruiting new students from underrepresented groups into cognitive science and providing graduate students with the opportunity to participate in cutting-edge multidisciplinary research. All materials produced by this program will be made freely available on the web. More generally, this program will foster new kinds of discourse between the various disciplines that make up cognitive science. Finally, by placing cognition within its proper embodied and situated context, the proposed training program may impact how society fosters and measures cognitive ability. IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The central goal of the Indiana University IGERT training program in "The Dynamics of Brain-Body-Environment Systems in Behavior and Cognition" was to train graduate students in the interdisciplinary perspectives of situated, embodied and dynamical approaches. A total of 26 faculty members participated in the program, training 31 IGERT fellows. In addition, although they were not funded by the IGERT program, 17 additional graduate associates participated in a subset of IGERT activities. We also ran an undergraduate internship program each summer in which a total of 22 undergraduate interns participated. These undergraduate students were drawn from Indiana University Northwest in Gary, Indiana, 80% of whose undergraduates come from groups underrepresented in science.

Our IGERT training program was comprised of a number of interrelated components. All trainees received either a stand-alone degree in Cognitive Science or a joint degree in Cognitive Science and one of a number of participating majors (Computer Science, History and Philosophy of Science, Informatics, Neuroscience, Philosophy, Physics or Psychological and Brain Sciences). The Cognitive Science component of the degree ensured that all students had a common core of knowledge. In addition, we developed two new required courses (a professional development course and an introduction to embodied cognition course) and two new electives (on brain networks and embodied approaches to the development of brain and behavior). We also developed a new colloquium series in which students received formal preparation for each speaker's visit and were provided with additional opportunities for both formal and informal interactions with speakers. A total of 25 nationally and internationally renowned speakers participated in this series. Every year, we held a public research showcase, providing a forum for trainees to present their work to the larger university and local community. Finally, support was provided for students to present their work at national and international conferences and to undertake short research internships at other universities in order to develop new skills and expand their research networks.

Research undertaken by our IGERT trainees, typically in interdisciplinary teams, fell into one of four broad themes: (1) Brain dynamics and connectivity, (2) Self-organization of individual behavior, (3) Processes of change and (4) Self-organization of group behavior. Research in theme 1 centered primarily on measuring and modeling the dynamic interactions among neurons and brain regions that are associated with cognition and behavior. Examples of work undertaken by our trainees in this area included the use of behavioral and neuroimaging studies to examine the acquisition of sign language by second language learners and the use of functional connectivity analysis to characterize age-related changes in the brain. Research in theme 2 combined theoretical and experimental work on how behavior and cognition arise from the dynamical interaction of internal neural activity, bodies and the external environment. For example, new tools from information theory were used to analyze the flow of task-relevant information throughout a brain-body-environment system. Research in theme 3 focused mostly on developmental questions, including how early hand-eye coordination in infant object play sets the stage for later word learning. Finally, research in theme 4 explored the patterns that groups of people and other agents form when they interact over time. Examples of our work in this area included studies of human/robot interactions and of the collective choices made by groups of people interacting competitively.
